all_paragraphs: Are you aspiring to be a data scientist but not sure what it takes to secure a job? In this article, I am going to outline the expectation of recruiters from the potential candidates in terms of

I will be explaining the ways to acquire experience to meet the job requirement and also about things that could help in improving your success rate in the interview process. If you have a preference for video format check out here — https://youtu.be/2CYQJ4IFeRA

Before going any further into the article, the details provided in this article are based on analyzing the job posting for data scientist position across a different job portal spanning different countries and trust me the patterns were exactly the same.
There are a number of tools commonly found in data scientist job posting. I will cover both the bare minimum required to meet the expectation and the good to have ones as well.
Almost 70% to 80% of data scientist job postings are requesting candidates with experience in one or more of the below programming languages,

If you are starting to learn data science then it would be preferable for you to choose Python over the other programming languages as it is currently very popular and it has huge community support. Programming skills are really important because a data scientist would spend about 80% of his time analyzing the datasets and it is really important to have good programming knowledge.
I am currently working on a 100 days data science tutorial series using python to cover all the concepts, techniques commonly used by a Data Scientist. If you are interested join the journey below
The next skill that is most sought after is the ability to build a good visualization. Some of the tools that could help here are

These above two skillsets (Programming and Visualization)are kind of must-have to get your resume shortlisted as these are pretty much used by data scientists every day. The other skillsets that could be very helpful but not really mandatory are

Data storage has become very cheap and hence a lot of organizations have started to store a lot of data than in the past. In order to make sense of these large datasets, it is critical to know tools from the Big data framework. The tools like Cassandra, Hadoop, Spark, Kafka are especially very useful in this scenario hence candidates with experience in some of these tools would be preferred over others.
Cloud platform offers many advantages such as

many of these were exclusive to only big corporations with a large IT team but now with the cloud technologies, these benefits are accessible to small companies with no dedicated IT resources as well.

Due to all these benefits, there is a trend of many companies adopting cloud technologies, hence with some cloud experience, you will be well placed to secure a job. It is easy to gain experience in the cloud platform, all major cloud platforms offer free credit or provide free tier which can be utilized to use and learn their platform. They also provide access to materials and training tutorials to learn more about their platform.
The technical and non-technical skill sets that are commonly expected from the candidates are captured below.
This is the ability of a person to ask relevant questions to collect all the required information and use logical reasoning and critical thinking in solving business problems.
Some of the key terms commonly found in the job descriptions that actually talk about your analytical skillset are,
“Strong analytical, statistical, and modelling skills, with experience manipulating and ‘making sense’ of data from disparate systems”
“Good Problem solving & Analytical Skills”
“Interprets results using a variety of techniques, ranging from simple data aggregation to complex data mining and statistical modeling”

Analytical thinking is critical for a data scientist as before commencing work on a business use-case it is important to have a thorough understanding of the problem statement. The good news is anyone can train themself on the analytical skills there are some techniques which can be used to improve this specific skillset. They are
Asking Questions (5W and 1H Technique): While working on a business problem ask as many questions as possible starting with the following,
Asking these questions will improve your critical thinking and with practice, this would become a habit. Just to practice this with a use-case let us consider the below example,
Now let us try asking more questions about this specific scenario using the 5W and 1H technique
These probing questions help in not only understanding the problem better but also in solution design

Gap Analysis: It is about understanding the current state as well as the expected future state and coming up with questions and actions that could help to move from the current state to the future state. For example, let us consider the below example
Current State: 8% percent Customers churn within one month of signing up to the platform
Future State: To reduce customer churning in their first month to 5% or below.

The next important skillset is business acumen which means the ability of an individual to understand the business context and the scenarios clear. A data scientist would generally work with various business teams and work with them to solve business problems hence it is essential for the data scientist to understand the problem in the right way. Some of the common phrases commonly used in the job description that is related to business acumen are,
“Proven experience in creating measurable business value through data science”
“Propose solutions and strategies to business challenges”
“Gathers required data and perform data analysis to support business needs”

Here the employers are just trying to get someone who is capable of solving any complex problem. This skillset is something that comes with experience in solving a variety of business problems. But if you are trying to start your career in data science or looking to transit into a career in data science then it is possible to get exposure to these areas by reading a variety of analytics case-studies. There are a number of case studies about how popular organizations use data to improve the customer experience or increase revenue. This would give you an idea about the bigger picture. You can definitely try to read about industry-specific case studies depending upon the companies you are trying to apply to.
My companies publish articles about how they make use of data and what kind of use-cases they are working on?

Now coming to the actual technical skillset, most data science job openings are expecting the applicant to possess some level of experience in working on a data science project. Some of the common phrases commonly used in the job descriptions are,
“Working on complex and extremely varied data sets”
“Analyze large amounts of information to discover trends and patterns”
“Deep understanding of predictive modeling, machine-learning, clustering and classification techniques, and algorithms”
“Build predictive models and machine-learning algorithms”
If you are interested to know about the life cycle of a data science project based on different maturity level, check this video

One best way to gain this experience is by working on kaggle use-cases. There are a number of data science competitions hosted on the kaggle platform and there are several learning exercises too. In most competitions, details would be provided about the problem, the data, and the objective to be achieved. While working in this competition you get to gain exposure to some of the below technical skill

No matter how hard you have been working on a business problem the real important things are communicating the insights to the relevant business stakeholders. The phrases commonly used in the job description related to communication skills are
“Ability to communicate complex quantitative analysis, analytic approaches, and findings in a clear, precise, and actionable manner”
“Supporting business needs for analysis and data visualization as required”
“Working closely with key stakeholders to understand business questions and execute data science projects that deliver business solutions”
“Communicate clearly and effectively to technical and non-technical audiences”
Below are a few things that could help in improving your communications skills

Let's assume that you have improved on the above-mentioned technical and soft skills so now how to ensure your Profile is shortlisted? There are some techniques to increase your chances of getting an interview call

Build a Portfolio: Take up hobby projects and work on them. Make them visible by publishing them in your git repository, still better would be to have a website with all your work and provide links in your resume
Improve your Online Presence: Some of the best place to promote yourself are,
and don’t forget to provide links to these platforms in your resume
References: Ask your friends/colleagues to endorse your skillsets and provide recommendations

To increase your chances of getting shortlisted always have a cover letter. And even have just one resume and use the same to apply for different roles. Try to read and understand the job description and then customize your resume and the cover letter to the role you are applying for, in this way your success probability will be greatly improved.
